page.title: 05RELIGION IN SADDLEWORTH
page.content:
Methodism at Diggle began under the influences of the Uppermill Methodist Society (est.1811) and the Bailey family, methodists from Holmfirth, who moved to Diggle in 1864. James Bailey, with John Sykes,( a manufacturer who lived at Holly Grove and owned Wrigley Mill), together established a Wesleyan Chapel and Sunday School at the mill. Previously some Methodist Services had been held occasionally at Kilngreen Day School, near Diggle Station. The movement grew fast and a new building was created in 1868 on its present site on Huddersfield Road at Weakey.
Anglicanism was based at Uppermill with Saddleworth Church as its focus. It was built around 1200 & was founded as a dependent chapelry of Rochdale. It is still a popular place of worship for local people and visitors.
